From what I've gathered, those experiments that supposedly disprove the idea of a classical universe don't actually show that the universe is not classical, but rather that the hidden variables we would need to access in order to predict it classically are unobtainable due to quantum effects like the uncertainty principle.

In other words, there are hidden variables; it's just impossible to measure them.

I want to agree with the Therm6000, who suggested that there must be an undiscovered basis about the randomness behind quantum uncertainty. I believe in an "explainable" universe. But on the other side, I'm also familiar with the idea of that every theory about the universe is correct until they fail to work so (this is rather a philosophical interpretation of the subject). Latter idea means basically that e.g. equations explaining the free fall of an object work until the time the object rises instead of falling under the effect of gravity (which seems to be highly impossible, but no one can suggest that it will NEVER happen, since no one lived until the eternity to prove it so).

Comparing these two, all you can say is, whatever we observe is true. This is the one and only axiom in science in my opinion (because if we start the idea of questioning whether our observations are true or not, things start to get very complicated). Other than that, every outcome resulting from the observations (assumed to be true) are just predictions on the modelling of the system behind the universe. With better observations we have better models, which eventually disproving the previous models.

For example, during the days, in which people believed the earth was flat, probably it was never argued for some time (either 10 years or hundreds of years). And everybody who heard about the theorem thought world is flat and not in another shape, UNTIL some people came up with better observations and eventually disproved the idea (which was the reality for people). So by that logic, no one can suggest that earth will ALWAYS have the shape of a planet until the eternity (excluding the possibility of something disastrous that can change its shape happening). That means, one day astronauts on ISS may wake up and see the earth is flat...

Quantum mechanics is in principle compatible with a deterministic world view as well, according to the De Broglie-Bohm theory for one.

The Bell theorem only says that a theory compatible with quantum mechanical results must violate either locality or realism. Basically, locality means that information cannot travel faster than light and realism means that measurement results are predetermined in some way (by 'hidden variables') rather than being randomly generated when you do the measurement.

The Bohm theory suggests that a sort of wave function emanates infinitely and instantaneously from all particles and by interference determines trajectories and states, preserving realism but sacrificing locality. For simple cases at least (double-slit experiment e.g.) the theory has been proven to curiously replicate established quantum mechanical results exactly.

The theory gets somewhat mathematically clunky (though ultimately free of contradiction as far as I know) in comparison with the much more widespread Copenhagen interpretation though. It gets more complicated than I care to research when you have to deal with instantaneous wave function propagation in contrast with the lack of absolute simultaneity in relativity. A foliation of space-time supposedly can fix that, but wikipedia can tell you more about that than I know :)

We can predict the nature of bigger things, like what happens when you drop an apple or when you jump. However, we cannot predict what exactly -will- happen to very, very, VERY small objects, like electrons; rather than tell you what state the electron will be in, we can only provide a probability that the electron will be in either state. Technically, we all have some wavenature, but the properties are only emergent at these smaller scales.

You can observe the energy, but you can't also observe the time (in the same way that one cannot observe the position, but also the momentum). 

If the universe was deterministic, causality would be at play rather than probability.

1. No, that is not what the wave function models. 
2. Not so. Breaking down that aspect of H.U.P., you simply find an expression that tells you that it is impossible to record both the momentum -and- the position of the object, but we can do that with macro-objects just fine. It's only when objects are incredibly small (the quantum level) that this behavior is observed.

Go to school and study quantum mechanics if you truly want to understand the nature of these things on a deeper level. It's not something that I can really explain to somebody without fully educating them on the subject. Suffice to say, everything can be modeled in probability. If I bump an electron up to a higher energy state, there's a chance it will either then decay (release heat), or cross to a triplet state and later decay. Each state is quantized, and ruled by probability.

Well, understand that we're talking about quantum mechanics, so we're talking about our universe at an incredibly small scale. If you toss a ball 12 cm in diameter at a wall at the exact same angle with the exact same velocity in a vacuum, you should always get the same result. Okay so we're wading out of my depth but here goes. No: neural activity is subject to the same quantum "laws" as all matter. The distinction to be made is that because a thought or decision is a definite arrangement of electrons in our brains, the wave has been collapsed. And, if you follow Hugh Everett III, every potential arrangement exists in its own universe. therefore: here i get up and make a sandwich; there I don't and stay at rest. My head hurts and  I want a sandwich.

I'm not saying Newtonian laws couldn't predict the mechanics of your specifics movements, only that they can't predict that you would move in the first place. As to the relationship between life and quantum mechanics; I've seen research that shows the lowest levels of brain activity (even in very simple organisms) are to some degree dictated by wave collapse functions. So our decisions are sort of a manifestation of quantum uncertainty, which could explain why we can be less than predictable.

Actually, the wave nature of particles is NOT due to the way we measure things. Early 20th century scientists thought all this uncertainty was due to our measuring techniques, but it turns out the universe simply demands that particles act like waves and that the motion of particles be unpredictable.

Nope! If you knew each particle's location with infinite precision, you would know nothing about their momenta because of the uncertainty principle! Where each of those atoms is located a few seconds later would be completely unpredictable! And not only that! Even if we could suspend the uncertainty principle for a moment and know the position and momentum of every particle in the universe at one point in time, where they're all located a few seconds later is still uncertain!

The details are a little bit complicated, but we actually have experimental proof that indeterminacy is BUILT IN to the universe. Even if you could somehow magically put an electron here and a proton there in a perfect vacuum and know everything about those two particles, wait precisely 15 seconds and then check how far the electron is from the proton, you simply could not predict where it would be! The universe simply does not permit you to make such predictions.

There's actually a fundamental difference between deterministic chaos - the thing you're describing - and quantum mechanical indeterminacy. As he briefly mentioned, scientists like Bell developed experimental tests for whether or not quantum mechanics could even in principal be deterministic. The irrefutable proof of these experiments states that NO! the universe is not deterministic.

It's a strange idea and it's difficult to accept but it's simply the way things are.

Technically, "classical physics" is assumed to hold the position of *local realism*, which assumes BOTH locality and predictability. Therefore, if locality is A and predictability is B, then for classical physics (AHEM, I mean, "local realism"), A ^ B, where ^ is the AND operator. Quantum Mechanics predicts ~A ^ ~B. The Bell experiments only proved that ~(A ^ B) is true. A, B, or both could be false, but they cannot both be true. So if A is false, B may still be true, a.k.a. "non-local realism".

Ahem-hem. Quantum Mechanics is NOT probabilistic. Saying anything physical is Inherently Probabilistic is an example of what is called the Mind Projection Fallacy. In short, it can be proven that probabilities are only ever something inside brains and similar systems. The fact that QM appears to be probabilistic is because we, as human experimenters are subject to it ourselves. This is basically what Richard Feynmann got the Nobel Prize for proving. (The QM, not the MPF).

As a conic section, a parabola is the intersection of a cone and a plane that is parallel to a side of the cone, and parallel lines by definition never meet. To say that they meet "at infinity" is meaningless babble. To put it another way, a parabola is an open curve; to say it is closed "at infinity", or symmetrical around an axis "at y=infinity", is also meaningless babble. Also you can plot a parabola without reference to any mythical second focus, so the distinction is an operational one.

And also, all the particles we know of *are* in the same space-time as us. And finally, we *can* measure them, it's just that there's no way to do it without changing them a bit in the process.

Why we can't just say we don't know whether the cat is dead or alive: Because there are phenomena that happen, such as something called interference, which show that it is not just one or the other - it has to be some combination of both. Read about the double slit experiment as a simple (but still subtle) example of this. 

And it doesn't have to do with our observations necessarily, that's just one example which is very relevant to people who observe. It is any time things interact.

Nope. This is a reasonable guess, and as you point out it is what we are used to. And indeed, this is what lots of scientists assumed was going on before they did experiments. But the evidence is in fact to the contrary. There are no hidden variables underlying the probabilities. Read about Bell's Inequalities, for example, to understand how we know this.

Another thing about cavalier dismissal: It might well be true that a lot of commenters on Youtube dismiss determinism without really understanding the evidence. That's not ideal, but it's okay - after all scientists know what they're talking about most of the time, so it doesn't hurt to just trust them. But if you think that scientists just dismiss determinism cavalierly, you are quite wrong. The evidence for probabilities is overwhelming, and you should dismiss it so cavalierly. ;)

Cavalier dismissal: Nope. It seems weird to us, since it's not what we're used to, but probabilities really is the way it is.

Clearly a complex set of rules we don't know yet: Nope. People used to think so until experiments said otherwise. Read about Bell's Inequalities, for example.

It wouldn't become orderly at a large scale: Nope. Think about taking an average. For more details, QED by Feynman has a nice simple description of how this works. Or read about the stationary phase approximation.

Sorry if I drop a lot of strange names, but check out the articles on Wikipedia. I suggest, in order: Heisenberg's uncertainty principle, conjugate variables, EPR and Bell's theorem. Also look for youtube videos on the dual split experiment. You may even want to look at that first. It won't take long to read those articles, but it may take quite a while to actually *understand* them - at least it did for me.

And yes, there are exactly Avogadro's number of molecules in exactly one mol of a substance. The uncertainty is not there, though it would (probably) be impossible to count them one-by-one. The uncertainty is in the conjugate variables, and it's not just the measuring effect. The EPR paradox illustrates nonlocality, and Bell's theorem (yes, another mathematical proof) demonstrates that nonlocality leads to randomness. That's not to say that there is no objective truth at all.

The thing is that you don't need to know every decimal in Avogadro's number. You only need to know that it is exactly Avogadro's number, if you understand what I mean? Just as we know that the circumference of a circle is exactly Pi * d. We don't need to know every decimal in Pi to know that it is true. The thing is that Heisenberg's uncvertainty principle is a theorem, i.e mathematical proof, so it's built in the formula of physics.

The formula becomes: dxdp >= h/2 (error in position times error in momentum is larger than, or equal to, h/2. Since p is v*m you can write this as: dxdv >= h/2m. If m is large (which is true in classical physics)...

It's statistics. If you have one gram of ordinary salt (NaCl) this corresponds to 1 mol (=Avogadro's number) of molecules. Avogadro's number is 6.02214X×10^23 or approximately 6 with 23 zero's behind it. With such big numbers, the distribution will be an almost exact match with the possibilities (i.e. if there is a 50% chance for something, almost exactly 50% of the molecules will be in that state). If you would throw a dice 6 * 10^23 times, almost exactly 1/6 of all throws would be a 6.

The basic claim made in the video is, unfortunately, a common held misunderstanding about  Bell's theorem. Violations of Bell's inequality rule out *locality* in physics, not *determinism*. If the predictions of standard quantum theory are correct, locality is out, but determinism is an open question.

Can we predict ANYTHING? All predictions are based on the assumption that the future will be like the past. But the only evidence we have that that will be true is that past futures have been like past pasts. But since all of these observations have occurred in the past, we can't apply them to the future unless we assume that the future is like the past, which forms a circular logical loop. So we can't ever predict anything with certainty; we can only have correctly predicted things in the past.

No because the gravitational field is actually different at every point.. this is why the planets revolve around the sun in elliptical orbits. On earth's surface we can simply approximate small trajectories using parabolas by assuming a constant force of gravity of ~ 9.8 m/s^2 downwards.

If you throw a ball near the surface of the Earth, then yes, it will follow an ellipse (if you use the Newtonian model) (unless you throw it reeeeealy hard; then it will follow a parabola or a hyperbola... for a while, until the Sun's gravity becomes dominant). Yet near the Earth's surface we normally just assume that the gravitational field is constant (not 1/r^2) and so you get a parabola as the shape of the trajectory.
